Obama: Recovery path hard, but challenge 'can be met'

"Yes, our path is harder — but it leads to a better place," President Obama said Thursday night during his nomination acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention. (AP)

Pictures

Democratic National Convention scenes

President Obama waved as he arrived to address delegates at the Democratic National Convention as crowds cheered "four more years." Jason Reed/Reuters
People waved American flags as the president delivered his speech to the Democratic National Convention in Charlotte. Kevork Djansezian/Getty Images
The Obama family met on stage after President Obama delivered the closing speech of the Democratic National Convention. Lynne Sladky/AP
Vice President Joe Biden and his wife, Dr. Jill Biden, watched as their son Beau spoke about his father. Kevork Djansezian/Getty Images
While addressing an enthusiastic crowd, Vice President Joe Biden accepted the Democratic nomination for vice president. Joe Raedle/Getty Images
Congressman Debbie Wasserman Schultz (left) and former Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords delivered the Pledge of Allegiance. Robyn Beck/AFP/Getty Images
Senator John Kerry waved after delivering his speech on the foreign policy accomplishments of President Obama. Jason Reed/Reuters
Actress Eva Longoria showed her support for President Obama, saying that she as a working movie actress did not need a tax break. Jason Reed/Reuters
Samara Jones, 4 months old, was held during the last day of the Democratic National Convention in Charlotte. Daniel Acker/Bloomberg
Actress Scarlett Johansson urged 18 to 24-year-olds to get out and vote for President Obama in November. J. Scott Applewhite/AP
  • Giffords inspires crowd at Democratic convention
  • Where'd the time go? Obama girls now young women

Content from Twitter

Massive barn fire kills 14 horses in N.H.

A barn fire at Perry Hill Farm in Bedford, N.H., killed at least 14 horses this morning while eight horses and a pig were able to escape, fire officials said. (Boston Globe)
  • Video Big Story: Three-alarm blaze kills horses in N.H.

EEE death of man 1st in Mass. in 2012

Officials said that the man, who was not identified, lived in Worcester County and was in his 70s, contracted the mosquito-borne virus. (Boston Globe)
